dk.statsbiblioteket.util
Class CachedCollator

java.lang.Object
  java.text.Collator
      dk.statsbiblioteket.util.CachedCollator
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Cloneable, java.util.Comparator<java.lang.Object>
@QAInfo(state=QA_NEEDED,
        level=NORMAL,
        author="te",
        comment="getCollationKey is poorly implemented due to the CollationKeyclass being final")
public class CachedCollator
extends java.text.Collator

Uses char-statistics to build a cache for the specified locale. Users should provide implementation-specific char-statistics in order to achieve the maximum possible speed-up. If no statistics are give, the characters from 0x20 to 0xFF are used. Note that this might give faulty sorting for some languages.

When two Strings are compared, it is checked if both Strings contains only characters from the char-statistics. If they do, comparison is done with the cache-table, which is fast. If any of the Strings contains other characters, comparison is done with the underlying Java-supplied Collator.

null is handled explicitly and always occur last.

The characters given must all be single-character comparable. Any characters used in more complex sorting rules (e.g. "aa" in Danish), should not be used for the cache. Note that the given characters are not required to be sorted, but should appear in order of popularity.

Field Detail

COMMON_NON_LETTER

public static final java.lang.String COMMON_NON_LETTER
ASCII-chars that are not special characters and not letters. It should be safe to use these as commonChars as they are normally compared 1:1. Normally it is advisable to extend this range with safe letters for the wanted locale.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

COMMON_AZ

public static final java.lang.String COMMON_AZ
ASCII-chars a-z and A-Z>. Depending on local rules for sorting, these might not be safe to use as commonChars (e.g. "aa" comes after "ab" in some standard danish sorts). Normally this will be used together with COMMON_NON_LETTER and other characters.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

COMMON_DK_SPECIFIC

public static final java.lang.String COMMON_DK_SPECIFIC
The danish letters æ, ø and å. For danish sorting, these are safe to use as commonChars, together with COMMON_NON_LETTER and COMMON_AZ.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

COMMON_SUMMA_EXTRACTED

public static final java.lang.String COMMON_SUMMA_EXTRACTED
Most commonly used characters from the corpus at Statsbiblioteket. If the local sorting rules are danish and if "aa" comes before "ab", these should be safe (and recommended) to use as commonChars. These chars are a "complete" list, meaning that they can be used directly as commonChars, without the need of extending.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

CHARSTATS

public static final java.lang.String CHARSTATS
If a CachedCollator is created without char statistics, it looks for the resource CHARSTATS. If the resource can be fetched, the content is used as char statistics.

See Also:
Constant Field Values
Constructor Detail

CachedCollator

public CachedCollator(java.util.Locale locale)
Create a cached collator with the characters from 0x20 to 0xFF as the most common characters. It is recommended to use the constructor CachedCollator(Locale, String) instead, in order to achieve maximum speed-up and valid comparisons.

Parameters:
locale - the wanted locale for the Collator.

CachedCollator

public CachedCollator(java.util.Locale locale,
                      java.lang.String mostCommon)
Create a cached collator with the given character statistics.

Parameters:
locale - the wanted locale for the Collator.
mostCommon - the most common characters for the given locale in the setting where the collator is used. It can contain any number of characters. See the class documentation for details. Duplicate characters are removed.
Example: "eaoi 0ntr1"...

CachedCollator

public CachedCollator(java.util.Locale locale,
                      java.lang.String mostCommon,
                      boolean spaceFirst)
Create a cached collator with the given character statistics.

Parameters:
locale - the wanted locale for the Collator.
mostCommon - the most common characters for the given locale in the setting where the collator is used. It can contain any number of characters. See the class documentation for details. Duplicate characters are removed. Example: "eaoi 0ntr1"...
spaceFirst - if true, the generated Collator is modified to sort spaces before other characters: {"a b", "aa"}.

CachedCollator

public CachedCollator(java.util.Locale locale,
                      boolean spaceFirst)
Create a cached collator with the given character statistics. This uses the characters from 0x20 to 0xFF as the most common characters. It is recommended to use CachedCollator(Locale, String) instead, in order to achieve maximum speed-up and valid comparisons.

Parameters:
locale - the wanted locale for the Collator.
spaceFirst - if true, the generated Collator is modified to sort spaces before other characters: {"a b", "aa"}.

CachedCollator

public CachedCollator(java.text.Collator collator)
Create a cached collator with the characters from 0x20 to 0xFF as the most common characters. It is recommended to use the constructor CachedCollator(Collator, String) instead, in order to achieve maximum speed-up and valid comparisons.

Parameters:
collator - the inner Collator that the cache is wrapped around.

CachedCollator

public CachedCollator(java.text.Collator collator,
                      java.lang.String mostCommon)
Create a cached collator with the given character statistics.

Parameters:
collator - the inner Collator that the cache is wrapped around.
mostCommon - the most common characters for the given collator in the setting where the cached collator is used. It can contain any number of characters. See the class documentation for details. Duplicate characters are removed. Example: "eaoi 0ntr1"...
